section.text: Unlike the major scale, three different minor scales exist.
Composers will often merge two of these scales - natural minor and harmonic minor - for a more pleasing sound.
Recall the diatonic triads of both scales.
Notice that many of the triads are the same.
Three pairs of triads (III, III+), (v, V), (VII, viiº) are different due to harmonic minor's raised seventh degree.
III is always used instead of III+. This is because III+, being an augmented chord, has a peculiar sound.
Because it contains a leading tone (and therefore is stronger), V is preferred to v. This does not mean that v cannot be used.
VII and viiº are both used equally. As you will later learn, each has a different function.
As you can see, the merged minor scale contains nine different diatonic triads.
